edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.ideal.common

Class IdealComparator

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.ideal.common.IdealComparator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.Comparator<NumericExpression>

    public class IdealComparator
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Comparator<NumericExpression>

    Comparator for ideal numeric expressions. This comparator is very heavily used in most numeric operations (e.g., adding and multiplying polynomials) so performance is critical.

    The order is defined as follows. First come all expressions of integer type, then all of real type. Within a type, first all the NTRationalExpression, then everything else. "Everything else" are instances of Polynomial. Polynomials are sorted first by degree: larger degree comes first (since that's the way you typically write them). Given two polynomials of the same degree:

    • if the two polynomials are monomials of the same degree, compare monics, then constants
    • to compare two monics of the same degree: use dictionary order on the primitive powers
    • to compare two primitive powers of same degree: compare the bases
    • If the two polynomials of the same degree are not monomials, then compare their leading terms. If those are equal, move to the next pair of terms. Etc.
    TODO: all of these expressions should be assigned order numbers for fast comparisons.

    • Method Detail

      • compareMonics

        public int compareMonics(Monic m1,
                Monic m2)
        Compares two Monics of the same type. A Monic of higher degree always precedes any Monic of lower degree. If they have the same degree, the dictionary order on their Primitive factors is used.
        Parameters:
        m1 - a non-null Monic
        m2 - a non-null Monic of the same type as m1
        Returns:
        a negative integer if m1 precedes m2, 0 if they are equal, else a positive integer

      • comparePrimitives

        public int comparePrimitives(Primitive p1,
                    Primitive p2)
        Compares two Primitives of the same type. All polynomials come before everything else.
        Parameters:
        p1 - a non-null Primitive
        p2 - a non-null Primitive of the same type as p1
        Returns:
        a negative integer if p1 precedes p2, 0 if they are equals, else a positive integer

      • compare

        public int compare(NumericExpression o1,
          NumericExpression o2)
        Compares two {IdealExpression}s, printing debugging output if the debug flag is true
        Specified by:
        compare in interface java.util.Comparator<NumericExpression>
        Parameters:
        o1 - a non-null IdealExpression
        o2 - a non-null IdealExpression
        Returns:
        a negative integer if o1 occurs before o2 in the total order; 0 if o1 equals o2; otherwise a positive integer
